conclusion: To determine when objects A and B are farthest apart, analyze their velocities over time and understand how their positions change relative to each other.
The graph shows the velocities of objects A and B as functions of time.
Object A starts with a high velocity at t0 and its velocity decreases over time.
Object B starts with zero velocity at t0 and its velocity increases over time.
The position of an object is the integral of its velocity over time.
For object A, its position at any time t is given by the integral of its velocity from t0 to t.
For object B, its position at any time t is given by the integral of its velocity from t0 to t.
The relative position between A and B at any time t is the difference between their positions.
We need to find the time t when the difference in their positions is maximized.
At t0, both objects start at the same position.
Between t0 and t2, object A is moving faster than object B, so it is moving ahead.
At t2, the velocities of A and B are equal, meaning A has been moving ahead but B is catching up.
Between t2 and t3, object B's velocity exceeds that of object A, meaning B is catching up and potentially overtaking A.
At t3, object B's velocity is at its maximum while object A's velocity is at its minimum.
The maximum separation occurs when the difference in their positions is greatest.
The maximum separation typically happens when the velocity difference changes sign, i.e., when object B starts moving faster than object A.
The maximum separation occurs around t2, just before object B starts overtaking object A.
The two objects are farthest apart at t2.
